reviewText:
As the title indicates, LEGO Star Wars: The Complete Saga is an amalgamation of two earlier games, LEGO Star Wars: The Video Game and Lego Star Wars II: The Original Saga.  I'm calling this an amalgamation as opposed to a compilation due to the fact that the gameplay is presented as a single uninterrupted experience, rather than as two that are separate and distinct.  Traveler's Tales has also added some additional content that was not present in either of the earlier stand-alone games.

LEGO Star Wars: The Video Game was the very first LEGO game developed by Traveler's Tales (henceforth referred to as TT), whereas the Original Saga was the second title they developed under the LEGO banner.  These titles form the foundation of what are now familiar gameplay features found in nearly all subsequently developed LEGO games.  The hallmark sense of humor is here (although like all of the earlier TT LEGO games, there is no spoken dialog), as are the simple LEGO building puzzle elements.  We find a familiar hub based level structure with each level branching from that central hub, and of course the LEGO collect-a-thon aspects make their debut here including the requisite stud collection, mini-kits, red bricks, golden bricks, etc.  So while a majority of the gameplay elements will be familiar to those who have previously dabbled in LEGO games, it's interesting nonetheless see the ways in which TT was still experimenting with their formula, solidifying what would become their trademark style.  This last bit is particularly interesting in the context of The Complete Saga, because you can see Traveler's Tales incorporating lessons learned and improving their games between the separate bookends of the Prequel Levels (featured in LEGO Star Wars: The Video Game), and the original trilogy levels (as featured in The Original Saga).  From a historical standpoint it's striking to see how quickly Traveler's Tales was able to deftly incorporate lessons learned from the first game and use them to improve the second game.  From a gameplay standpoint though, this creates a bit of dissonance.  Stylistically, the Original Saga is a much more robust game.  The levels are longer and more complex, the puzzles are generally more interesting, the graphical elements are improved upon, etc.  So while the levels in Complete Saga are presented seamlessly, in practice you will notice a very definitive division between the older (prequel) levels and the newer (original saga) levels.  Speaking as a bit of a Star Wars nerd I'm happy that the Original Saga levels are the ones with better gameplay.

As I mentioned before, the gameplay elements here will be very familiar to anyone who has played TT LEGO games before.  Given the ubiquitous nature of these games, you probably already know whether this game is for you.  If you love the LEGO formula you'll find a lot to love here.  If the 'break everything in sight collect-a-thon' turns you off, well … these aren't the droids you're looking for.  <groan>  As I mentioned earlier, TT was still developing their trademark style in these games, so even those who have enjoyed more recent LEGO titles might find some of the elements featured here to be a bit rudimentary.  The controls are (naturally) very familiar, but at the same time feel slightly 'looser' than later LEGO titles.  Switching between characters can be a bit tedious since TT had yet to develop the character wheel system seen in more recent titles.  This means that you need to stand directly next to the character you wish to switch to, and since you often have several characters crowding in on you this can lead to several instances of switching to the wrong character.  This can be slightly rage inducing when you're under attack.  Speaking of computer controlled characters, they are basically useless while not under your direct control, and even worse you may find many circumstances in which they will actively become a hindrance.  There were several circumstances in which I would need to destroy one of my computer controlled allies simply to create a clear line of fire.  Get the heck out of the way Chewie!  And while I'm on this topic, I won't lie, sometimes I would randomly just lay a beat down on Jar-Jar, because … Jar-Jar.

I need to make special mention of the collectible elements in this game, because that aspect has really been dialed to eleven.  If you're like me and you like to unlock everything these games have to offer, well … you're going to be here a while.  You'll need to play through every level no less than four times.  You'll play a level once in story mode which will unlock free play mode.  Then you'll need to play through free play mode to clean up any of the standard remaining goals in that level.  Once you've completely finished the episode you'll unlock Challenge and Super Story modes.  So you'll play each level again in Challenge mode to retrieve the blue mini-kits, and lastly you'll play through them yet again in Super Story mode which is a time-based score attack and simply adds to your completion percentage.  Four times for every level.  Once you couple this with the fact that this game features unskippable cut scenes, it can all start to become a bit … tedious.  As I mentioned, this part really only applies to completionists, so your mileage may vary significantly in this regard.  I think this is another area in which TT was still figuring out the formula, which in this case meant finding an acceptable line between collect a bunch of unlockables" and "OMFG

reviewText:
So this is Lego Star Wars - The Complete Saga, it's the sequel to Lego Star Wars II, which was in turn a Sequel to Lego Star Wars. If you've played this as a kid on the Ps2 like I have, you know what you're getting into, but regardless here's a review.

The Complete Saga features the 6 pre-force awakens episodes - the prequel era episodes through the original trilogy - and levels are based on scenes and events in the movies.

So the game starts you off in the first level of Episode 1, the Phantom Menace, in the Trade Federation blockade ship Episode 1 largely started in. You play as Qui-Gon and Obi-Wan and try to escape from the ship, the first level serving as a tutorial on how the functions of the game work, such as the force, building, studs, minikits, deflecting blaster shots, and access panels only characters can access.

After you finish that level, you're free to go to any of the other episodes of the Prequels/OT. Which is rather nice and actually really well thought out, while you can continue with the plot of TPM, you're allowed to jump to any of the other episodes and start off at level 1. You don't have to complete all the levels of TPM to move on to AOTC, for example. The game is really open and free, and as such comes off as a really good title.

The gameplay is just what you would expect from a Lego game, it's fun, interactive, and runs great. Most props are composed of Legos in the game, with the exception of environments (Which still look good) and it gives the game and levels a great atmosphere that you expect from a Lego game.

As you go through the game, you can unlock more things with money, be it custom characters, cheats, or hints from the store. And can use the characters when replaying missions.

Meanwhile, the explanation of the story in the game is arguably better than how it's explained in some of the films. This being an early Lego game,(since modern Lego games seem to have dialogue) there is no dialogue and thus the cutscenes explaining the story have to rely on only visuals to get the plot across, and it's honestly genius how they explain some of the Episode Plots. The cutscenes for the Phantom Menace Episode, for example, are not only more funny than the actual film it's based on, but the game's explanations of the story in the episode in the cutscenes more easily explain the plot of the film, and you're able to get a gist of what's going on. Which, in the case of TPM, where the conflict is based on a trade blockade dispute,(and honestly one of the most difficult plots to explain due to how messy it is for a Star Wars film) is very important for game cutscenes to be short and to the point, and this game is great at explaining stuff by way of 15 second cutscenes.

The game runs fantastically and I've yet to find a PC of mine that cannot run it, it's greatly optimized and allows for great customization of settings, including the controls. Though the mouse cannot be bound as a key, which confused me until I realized that the setup of the game is for it to be entirely played without a mouse, which is cool, but if you have a controller I suggest you use it for this.

If you're looking for online Multiplayer though, you won't find it here, the multiplayer service is local (i.e two people would have to share the PC screen) but I don't blame the game for this as the original game on the consoles was also local and without online multiplayer connection. Though if you want to set up Steam Big Picture and grab some remotes, it's probably possible to mimic a console.

reviewText:
For those of you familiar with the LEGO series, here is one of originals that set the tone.

For those of you who aren't, you have the cute LEGO figurines playing through a somewhat stylized version of the Star Wars Saga (episode 1 to 6), breaking LEGO pieces for studs along the way. After playing through in story mode, you can come back in free-play mode that allows you to switch between any character you unlocked. This allows you, for example, to use Princess Leia to grapple up to a ledge, and then switch to R2D2 to open a switch to open a door that was inaccessible in story mode.

The game is easy but fun, and has a TON of collectables, unlock-able bonus levels, and such.

reviewText:
Being a compilation of the first two LEGO Star Wars games developed by Traveller's Tales, The Complete Saga stands resolutely as a lot of bang for your buck. Particularly if you're a completionist because finishing the game as-is will probably leave you at about 50% completion rate with plenty more to find in form of unlockable characters, gameplay gimmicks and additional levels.

As a game it's your action adventure fare with platforming as you go through the entire movie hexalogy. I have to point out the game does suffer from having vehicle levels with extremely loose controls that simply end up getting in the way of things, though. The Complete Saga even retroactively adds some vehicle sections to prequel episodes to keep the entire experience consistent. It does benefits from eschewing voice acting in favor of simple gesticulation which leads to a lot of funny scenes as characters try to convey some plot points. Speaking of characters they operate based on different types ranging from Jedi and Sith aka Force users to droids and bounty hunters, each with their own specific utility which you will need to use in order to complete each level to its fullest. In practice this means you'll be going back to already finished levels in order to complete them as you unlock more characters. You'll also be spending omnipresent studs you gather throughout the game as currency to unlock things.

This write-up may seem to be a bit all over place, but that's because I find myself fighting for words. It's a really great game and should not be dismissed as a cash-in game, not even close. Just beware – completionist mentality is recommended.

The game you played as a kid is back! Journey through all six films and experience a story that is legend. There is no dialogue ripped from the films, a plus for prequel-haters. I've seen all six films and the story is more fun to play through than watching the films ever was.

This really is a good deal. Lego isn't too keen on sales so just buy this one when you have the cash. I've bought this gem a total of four times.  The first two were on the PS2 (The game used to be split between the two trilogies), the third was on PS3 for that 1080p shine and merger of both games. Now it's found a home in my Steam library. With the addition of Vsync, graphics options, sixty frames per second, and 1080p screen resolution, I can safely say this is *the best version of Lego Star Wars*!

reviewText:
The Star Wars fanbase is a tumultuous one. At the time of Lego Star Wars’ release, the franchise consisted of a fantastic trilogy, an awful trilogy and a mess of other content of varying quality. There are various groups of Star Wars fans with different opinions—some defend the prequel trilogy wholeheartedly while others are more down-to-earth, insisting that there hasn’t been a good Star Wars film in over 30 years.

One of the biggest strengths of Lego Star Wars is that it doesn’t seem reminiscent of either trilogy, instead bringing forth its own style of simple, family-friendly humour and simplifying down the plots of all six Star Wars film into a cartoony mashup of the popular sci-fi series and the equally popular line of children’s toys.

In theory, it’s a bizarre concept, but in practice it works rather well. The Lego adaptations of the various sets and characters from the films look fantastic, providing a wacky, cartoony art direction complemented by the game’s child-oriented sense of humour. It consists mostly of slapstick comedy by way of over-the-top animation. In fact, the graphics overall are actually very good. While the ‘photorealistic-in-2005’ textures on some of the non-Lego environmental objects are a little ugly, everything that’s made of the titular plastic bits looks great. It’s quite amusing to see well-known icons of the franchise like the famous Millennium Falcon rendered as an excessively detailed Lego model.

There is, however, a bit of a disparity in overall visual fidelity between the episodes taken from the original 2005 Lego Star Wars game and the 2006 sequel. The original trilogy characters taken from Lego Star Wars II each have unique animations and each has an exotic look about him. Han Solo winks knowingly at the camera as he twirls his laser pistol on his finger before he holsters it, Darth Vader simply taps his foot in front of security cameras rather than give the wave of acknowledgement an average Stormtrooper would. My favourite is the animation that plays when you try to punch Princess Leia as Lando Calrissian—rather than attack her, he plants a gentle kiss on her hand and bows. It’s the little details like this that make Lego Star Wars such a joy to look at.

Characters from the prequel trilogy, however, all share the same set of generic animations. I didn’t notice any of the detailed animations with them, and there was even one character I noticed who kept the ‘generic Lego smile with soulless black eyes’ expression regardless of the situation he was in. It was unnerving and honestly just felt like a bit of a cop-out. I understand that these characters were from an older game, but I think if the developer is going to re-release both of these games in a package like The Complete Saga, the least that could be done is an update to bring these parts of the game up to the quality level of the original trilogy.

Surprisingly, the quality gap doesn’t stop at the animations. Allow me to give an example. Characters from the original trilogy who use laser pistols have access to a ‘dodge’ move, allow them to quickly step out of harm’s way in combat. This feature wasn’t implemented in the original game, so the characters from it cannot use this ability. This is baffling laziness on the developer’s part, and it actually makes about a quarter of the game’s characters obsolete by comparison. It’s especially embarrassing when you consider how much effort it would take—all the characters are almost exactly the same model, and all the animations are already in the game. In fact, the entire amalgamation is rife with this kind of laziness. All that’s really been done to the original game's content is a slight graphical tweak. Don’t get me wrong, everything that’s here is fantastic, even the older stuff, but I just don’t quite understand why a developer wouldn’t take the time to even out the quality so that even the content from the 2005 game feels like less of a re-tread and more like a remake.

The gameplay itself is essentially a 3D platformer with an emphasis on combat, puzzles and collectible items. The levels are beautifully rendered as Lego models, though there are a lot of models and textures designed to look like real-world objects. It’s a little disappointing that not everything’s made of Lego, but it still a treat to look at.

The controls are sufficient. I did find that far too many actions are bound to the B button, and the vehicle-based levels are an absolute nightmare in general, but the ground-based levels control well enough. The combat is extremely simple—it’s not really viable to use more than two buttons—but I still found it engaging, perhaps because of the (mostly) superb animations.

Lego Star Wars uses sounds taken almost exclusively from the films, and it works fantastically. John Williams' score speaks for itself, but it’s not even just that—every sound effect is authentic to the point where just listening to the game’s audio could leave you thinking you were actually watching one of the films. The way the characters collide with a soft click is so charming, and fits with the game’s overall style perfectly.

The Complete Saga has a whole lot of content. There are 37 levels total, 20 side missions (given out by the illustrious Jabba the Hutt), 160 characters and a variety of vehicles. I do have a problem with the character roster, however. Out of the huge selection, there are maybe 8 that aren’t just remodels of other characters. To make matters worse, a lot of characters are just another character minus one ability. Every Jedi is identical, and every Sith is just a Jedi with an extra ability, thereby invalidating the need to ever play as a Jedi outside of story mode. There are a ton of other comparisons that can be drawn up, which I’d bet would invalidate over half the roster. I get that they want to include everyone from the films, but it feels like they could have buffed up a lot of the weaker guys. Sure, that may end up with most characters being reskins of others, but that’s still a better alternative to what happens now.

On the topic of content, a lot of The Complete Saga’s replayability feels pretty contrived. For instance, within each and every level there are 10 ‘minikit canisters’ that will give the player a new vehicle once collected. The problem is, most of these canisters can only be acquired using abilities that the player does not have in story mode, thereby mandating a second playthrough of the level in ‘free play’ mode to reach 100% completion. ‘Free play’ mode is the same as story mode, but it removes the cutscenes and allows the player to choose one of their unlocked characters to play as throughout the level. They may then swap between a select group of characters on the fly. This party of characters is selected based on their abilities, ensuring that you will always have access to every ability in the game as long as you’re in free play mode. It’s good fun to go back through early levels searching for collectibles as Darth Vader (obviously the best character), but I just wish it didn’t feel so much like the game was trying to force multiple playthroughs. It’s a minor criticism, however. I still had a great time in free play mode.

Overall, The Complete Saga does feel like a bit of a lazy compilation of two fantastic games, but I’m still going to recommend it based purely on the outstanding quality and unique style of those original games.

reviewText:
Takes me back to the days of playing this beautiful game on the PS2 and Wii. The PC version is basically the Wii version with PC optimisations, although I swear I can see some extra content in the PC version...

The Wii version in and of itself was incredible, basically merging the original two PS2 games. In keeping with the Wii game, this is also incredible. It's fun, and a hell of a lot of it. At their core, Lego games are pretty basic: Get your Lego minifigures and go nuts in some themed setting, which appeals amazingly to children (Exhibit A being myself about 10 years ago). But the more intricate features (gold/power brick unlocks, challenge mode, etc.) are enough to keep more hardened gamers (Exhibit A being myself right now) coming back for more.

And it's Star Wars. Jar Jar actually has a purpose in this game, and you can quite successfully fight Darth Vader with Darth Vader in Free Play mode.

Brilliant game, and the nostalgia rush makes it even better.
9.5/10

This is the third LEGO game I've played, and I can definitely say they have improved over the years. This brought me a lot of nostalgia, and runs very well as it should.  The gameplay is solid and has good humor.  However, the controls are rough if you're using a keyboard and mouse.

There is no mouse support whatsoever, not even on menus.  You can rebind all the keys to any buttons on keyboards, joysticks, etc.  I highly recommend playing this with a controller or even a joystick.

As with most Lego games, you can play local co-op on a single computer, which is a great feature.  Supsequently, there is no online co-op.  However, co-op is nearly impossible with a keyboard.  Essentially, one player uses one half of the keyboard and the other player uses the second half.  This isn't the issue though.  The problem is that regular keyboards cannot register more than 4 keys being pressed at the same time, so sometimes one player won't be able to attack or jump.  If you have a mechanical keyboard, this isn't an issue.  Ideally both players should have controllers, but either player can bind their controls to any kind of input peripheral.

I once said, in another review, that I used to play Lego Indiana Jones with my little brother a lot when I was a kid, but it was difficult because of our lack of skill and faulty hardware at every level. Well, there's a secret backstory for that review, because I'm fairly sure that Lego Star Wars was the first game I ever played, and the conditions and brother were even MORE trying then. The disc and laptop were worse, we were younger and thus worse at games, the shared keyboard was even more compact, and we only ever got to play it on long car rides, where every bump on the road knocked the disc around in the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ holder and spawned another game-breaking glitch. Truly a crucible of early gaming.

Well, it wasn't the entire thing. The version we had was just Lego Star Wars 2, which was Episodes 4-6 (which happen to be the ones I just completed the story mode for). We didn't get the full package until a couple of years later, when it was one of the two games we got along with our new Wii for Christmas. To justify its existence as 2 games stapled together, it added a few new features, like new bonus levels, a 1v1 mode, and powerups scattered throughout the levels, all of which are fairly pointless. As to the levels themselves, episodes 4-6 are far stronger than episodes 1-3, for what I think are a few reasons: 1, more interesting things happen in the originals; 2, it came out a year later, when all the developers had finally earned their game design degrees; 3 (and this is complete speculation), the devs probably had more love for the originals than for the new ones; and 4, I have more nostalgia for the parts I played first and therefore those parts are better. Shut up, it's true.

And as for the game itself? Well, it's not nearly as polished as Lego Indiana Jones (the devs clearly learned more the more games they made, which is a trend I support), but for what it is, it's fantastic. Coming back, not only was I realizing how much fun I was having in just the first level, but I was also experiencing almost crying levels of nostalgia for things that had all come rushing back from almost a decade ago. I remembered that puzzle with the crane! I remembered wanting to be R2-D2 or Captain Antilles! Oh my God! Rebel Friend! I remembered Rebel Friend!

Anyway, nostalgic tangents aside, the same rules apply for this as they do for Lego Indiana Jones; everything's either good game design, funny and/or goofy, or probably broken (or John Williams's score). Tell you what, if I ever make a game, I'm going to hire all the animators from Traveler's Tales, because those guys know how to do an incredible amount with very little. Look up the intro cutscene for Episode 6, Stage 5. See how they convey all (or at least most of) the conflict and emotion of the scene in the movie, in the space of about 30 seconds, using absolutely no dialogue, with F*CKING LEGO FIGURES? These people are masters!

Also, they managed to nail the vital Stormtrooper balance of adorably bad but taken completely seriously. You should buy the game for just that.

P.S. If you think it's just a game for kids, go to the Zero Punctuation for Lego Indiana Jones and listen to what he has to say about kid-oriented vs. family-oriented. This one's family-oriented.

P.P.S. Like the Indiana Jones review, I haven't played the whole thing through here but I did when I was younger, and I remember all of it.

The Pros
This gem has lasted 10 solid years, providing a memorable spitscreen, pick-up-and-play approach that makes it fun to play with others.  The story mode itself has brief, adapted cutscenes from the actual films that make me feel warm inside.  Combine that with a vast array of characters, unlockable (not downloadable) content, quality sound, and a lovable asthetic; and you've got a solid 20 hour experience that will stick with you for a while.

The Cons
I said it's a gem, but even gems get dirty.  While it shines in sheer quantity of gameplay and multiplayer, the game has a few other problems.  It feels slightly dated, even though it's very similar graphically to any other recent LEGO release.  As someone no longer in elementary/middle school, the controls feel a little clunky, the combat overly-simplified, camera angles frusterating, and overall experience underwhelming.  I loved piloting the X-wing on the surface of the LEGO Death Star, but had no clue what I was really doing and just held down the fire button.

My Verdict
Though it pales in comparison to other games (Like Marvel Super Heroes) by simply feeling dated, I genuinely believe that it's a game that everyone deserves to experience.  Grab it when it's on sale, a friend, and play for a few hours to feel like that 6th-grade stud hoarder everyone is inside.  Instructions not included.

The combat and puzzle elements are what is to be expected from a LEGO game (and if you're not familiar with them, what I mean by this is that they're nothing too special), but it's LEGO... and Star Wars... so the game has to be good! Out of all the annual series of video games, the LEGO series has been, by far, my favorite. I mean, you get to experience these movies so deeply embedded in pop culture in a new light with LEGO's quirky and charming humor. And this is the one that truly started it. That is not to say past LEGO games were bad, LEGO island being a nostalgic and fun experience for me. But it's LEGO Star Wars that truly kicked it up a few notches to what it currently is right now.

The Complete Saga has you playing through the prequels trilogy and the original trilogy. Each episodes are seperated into six missions based on the more important parts of their respective movies. But though you may think this game is just about going through levels in LEGO form, there is much to do. Each level has Red Bricks (Which are little extras that give you some new or enhanced abilities), you also get to collect 10 minikits which are hidden in the levels (sometimes completely out of your reach because your current set of characters do not possess the ability to reach it). Collecting studs allows you to buy characters and vehicles and collecting enough of them during missions gets you True Jedi status (which gives you a Gold Brick). Upon completion of the story mode, you unlock Free Play and Challenge mode. Free Play has you playing through the level with a set of randomized characters specifically for their abilites to get some of the minikits you cannot normally get during story mode, giving this game some actual replay value. Challenge has you going after 10 blue minikits within the level altough you are now on a timer and the location of these minikits has been mixed up a bit. So, basically, if you are going for 100%, you'll get to experience these levels minimum three times.

This game's soundtrack is also from the movies, which is a plus within itself. The complete Saga features also 2 player co-op (local), 6 bonus levels that were in the original installments of these two games' seperate releases (Harder versions basically). On top of that, there are 160 Gold Bricks in the game. You get 3 per level: 1 for beating the level in story mode, 1 for collecting all minikits, 1 for obtaining True Jedi status. 14 can be bought in the Mos Eisley Cantina and 6 for the aforementioned Bonus levels. All in all, you have a crap ton to do in this game.

With the plethora of content, replay value, addictive gameplay and the chance to exprience Star Wars in LEGO form, I absolutely recommend this game. Nearly 10 years later, this game is still fun and has yet to show its age.

TL;DR: A great nostalgia trip for Lego and/or Star Wars fans, but rough around the edges and it shows.

I had the original two Lego Star wars games for Gamecube way back in the day. I played and enjoyed the hell out of both of them. So you can imagine my excitement when I realized that I could play both, in one game, on PC. I picked this title up in the winter sale and I've been playing it off and on since then.

It's just as fun as I remember it. The absence of their cringeworthy dialogue and forced love story make the prequels much more enjoyable, though it might be hard to understand if you don't already know the plot. The slapstick and Lego dismemberment gags never get old. There's easter eggs hidden everywhere, encouraging exploration, and the game's puzzles are challenging and rewarding enough to solve for players of any age without getting frustrating (most of the time).

You can play as all your favorite characters, along with many others whose names you never knew and never really cared about, like Grand Moff Tarkin or Ki-Adi-Mundi. Most of the main characters have unique and sometimes hilarious melee animations, like Princess Leia who ♥♥♥♥♥slaps everyone, or Chewbacca who will leap on stormtroopers and rip their arms off (it's all bloodless Lego gore so it's okay for kids, obviously).

However, no game is without sin and this one commits quite a few of them.

A lot of the optional characters, especially the blaster-wielding ones, have little differentiation between them besides their general appearance, so you'll probably just end up using Luke Skywalker (Jedi), Boba Fett (grown-up), and Darth Vader most of the game.

The most glaring flaws are perhaps the myriad of bugs littered throughout the game, from texture, shadow, and Z-ordering glitches (where background meshes pop through foreground ones) to areas where the Lego studs you're supposed to collect (as currency) simply clip through the floor or walls or other decorations and disappear. Since this game was released in 2009, I very much doubt that these issues will ever be resolved.

Some puzzles are far more tedious than challenging; oftentimes the solution is obvious but requires a lot of work simply to make it seem more difficult than it actually is. This is a trap that many otherwise very good puzzle games (like Portal and The Talos Principle) fall into to pad out their runtimes, and I wish it would stop. Some of the optional puzzles have such obscure and nonsensical solutions" that you're basically just trying to guess what the game designer was thinking.

Lego Star Wars is a game I consider a classic from my childhood and the Star Wars VII hype got me to pick up this game in the Winter sale (Damn you marketing tactics!). This doesn't mean I think it's one of the best games I ever played as a kid but it's one I have very fond memories of and pretty much anyone I talk to about it has played it at some point. It's that perfect blend of co-op, collectathon, movie tie-in that's just great to play when I'm not feeling something very intense and just want to relax.

The game is most certainly flawed, the artificial difficulty and lack of any complex combat is the one of the big complaints; I never felt challenged playing this game but I also died a lot because the game throws enemies at you non stop and while they only take one hit to kill avoiding all the blaster bolts can prove annoying if you aren't a character with auto dodge. This really slows down the game and while I don't expect the most from the combat every lightsaber battle was jump attack, jump attack, jump attack ect. It's impossible to hit someone while they're blocking with anything other than the air attacks which are undodgeable by the AI if you're in range. I know this is a kids game and not meant to be challenging but after a while even kids would find this tedious at best.

The lack of online co-op is my biggest grind with this game. At first I thought it was an issue with it being such an old game that relies on single screen co-op but after checking other Lego games I realized that it was nothing more than a trend of laziness. I did manage to take my laptop to a friend's and play it with them and it was great fun except that save files are harder than needs be to locate and impossible to get working on a separate machine to the one it came from meaning we had to start a fresh with none of the cool characters I'd unlocked. Besides some of the vehicle levels being a bit lackluster and Superstory being total BS and a lazy way to recycle content these are my only real complaints with the game so from here on out it's all positive.

The Lego formula has practically been perfected now but that doesn't mean it wasn't always great. Star Wars has so much charm in its cutscenes and is very humoresque due to it's recognizable and lovable characters acting out the Star Wars story in a silly and joking way. There is so much to do in this game and so much to find. While some levels practically hand you the collectibles some can prove a real challenge to find, but if your smart you can aim to collect the stud multipliers and minikit/red brick detector red bricks giving you a hint on in which direction there is a collectible. There's also some extra game modes in the complete saga that add that make 100%ing this game a real journey as you try collect all the gold bricks.

One of the best things about Lego Star Wars is that it's well, Star Wars. Playing all your favourite Jedi battle it out on all those great planets from the Star Wars universe is immensely entertaining and even more fun in Lego. I would enjoy this game even if it wasn't Star Wars but the real heart and charm of the game comes from seeing your favorite scenes re-acted in Lego form.

There were dull moments while playing this game but I thoroughly enjoyed it and I felt both a sense of fulfillment and emptiness once I reached 100% which shows just how great this game is. May the force be with you all.

TL;DR: A great nostalgia trip for Lego and/or Star Wars fans, but rough around the edges and it shows.

I had the original two Lego Star wars games for Gamecube way back in the day. I played and enjoyed the hell out of both of them. So you can imagine my excitement when I realized that I could play both, in one game, on PC. I picked this title up in the winter sale and I've been playing it off and on since then.

It's just as fun as I remember it. The absence of their cringeworthy dialogue and forced love story make the prequels much more enjoyable, though it might be hard to understand if you don't already know the plot. The slapstick and Lego dismemberment gags never get old. There's easter eggs hidden everywhere, encouraging exploration, and the game's puzzles are challenging and rewarding enough to solve for players of any age without getting frustrating (most of the time).

You can play as all your favorite characters, along with many others whose names you never knew and never really cared about, like Grand Moff Tarkin or Ki-Adi-Mundi. Most of the main characters have unique and sometimes hilarious melee animations, like Princess Leia who ♥♥♥♥♥slaps everyone, or Chewbacca who will leap on stormtroopers and rip their arms off (it's all bloodless Lego gore so it's okay for kids, obviously).

However, no game is without sin and this one commits quite a few of them.

A lot of the optional characters, especially the blaster-wielding ones, have little differentiation between them besides their general appearance, so you'll probably just end up using Luke Skywalker (Jedi), Boba Fett (grown-up), and Darth Vader most of the game.

The most glaring flaws are perhaps the myriad of bugs littered throughout the game, from texture, shadow, and Z-ordering glitches (where background meshes pop through foreground ones) to areas where the Lego studs you're supposed to collect (as currency) simply clip through the floor or walls or other decorations and disappear. Since this game was released in 2009, I very much doubt that these issues will ever be resolved.

Some puzzles are far more tedious than challenging; oftentimes the solution is obvious but requires a lot of work simply to make it seem more difficult than it actually is. This is a trap that many otherwise very good puzzle games (like Portal and The Talos Principle) fall into to pad out their runtimes, and I wish it would stop. Some of the optional puzzles have such obscure and nonsensical solutions" that you're basically just trying to guess what the game designer was thinking.

Why people say that keyboard controls suck when they're changeable.

Why people think that you need the mouse on this game.

One hand can cover movement and two buttons. That leaves two fingers on your other hand that have to be somewhere on the keyboard. The other two that you never need quickly could be put right near them so you can use a third finger and then MOVE one of the others to press the other button should you need it.
